intro: Umbilicus libanoticus var. steudelii, commonly known as the Lebanon umbilicus, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its umbellate inflorescence. The plant features finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or limestone areas. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
